titles: Ukraine: Putin 'apologizes' to Israeli PM over Russia's Holocaust remarks — live updates
descriptions: Russia's President Vladimir Putin discussed the war in Ukraine with Israel's Prime Minister Naftali Bennett after his foreign minister infuriated Israel with comments about Hitler. Follow DW for the latest.

titles: Champions League: Real Madrid, Karim Benzema and the greatest remontada of all
descriptions: Karim Benzema was the hero once again as Real Madrid produced another stunning comeback to shock Manchester City and reach the Champions League final. Impossible, unthinkable, unimaginable - yet not for the first time.

titles: RECOMMENDED — Western companies are leaving Russia, taking Russian jobs with them. DW spoke to people who are now unemployed.
descriptions: More and more Russians are losing their jobs due to western sanctions on Russia, and some are having to painfully rethink their future. With some sanctions' effects yet to be felt, the number of unemployed could grow.

titles: Habeck: LNG lawsuit hinders German efforts to move away from Russian energy
descriptions: The Economy and Climate Minister says the legal action against the accelerated construction of an import terminal for liquefied natural gas will make it harder to move away from Russian energy.

titles: Moldova: 'I'm worried about the children'
descriptions: In villages close to the breakaway Moldovan region of Trans-Dniester, many residents fear they could be dragged into Russia's war on Ukraine. For some, the current events bring back painful memories of conflict.

titles: WHO estimates nearly 15 million deaths linked to COVID pandemic
descriptions: The World Health Organization said more than twice as many people died as a result of the COVID pandemic than official data shows, if including deaths of other causes that might not have occurred in more typical times.

titles: Zelenskyy tells donor conference: 'Freedom must protect and provide'
descriptions: Poland and Sweden hosted an international donors' conference to raise aid for Ukraine. President Volodymyr Zelenskyy urged donors to show that "freedom" protects better than "tyranny."

titles: Why is India falling in the World Press Freedom Index?
descriptions: India fell eight places in the World Press Freedom Index, down to 150 out of 180 countries. Critics say the ranking reflects increased pressure and violence against journalists.

titles: Think 8 hours of sleep is best? Think again!
descriptions: Are you 38 or older? Then you may want to rethink how much sleep you truly need. A team of international researchers has found that less is more.

titles: Ukraine conflict: Steinmeier and Zelenskyy have 'good, constructive, important conversation'
descriptions: The German president and Chancellor Olaf Scholz have both been invited to Kyiv, according to Frank-Walter Steinmeier's office. He had planned to go to Kyiv in April, but was told not to come on the eve of his trip.

titles: 5 things we can learn from Marlene Dietrich
descriptions: Marlene Dietrich died on May 6, 1992 — 30 years ago. She fled the Nazis and conquered Hollywood. She remains a role model in times of crisis.

titles: Ukraine: How farm vehicles stolen by Russia were remotely disabled
descriptions: Russian soldiers looted combine harvesters and tractors worth millions of dollars from Ukraine, according to a media report. But the machinery was deactivated remotely before it could be put to use.

titles: Brittney Griner's Russian detention highlights WNBA's growing problem
descriptions: The WNBA is seen as the world's best women's basketball league. However, the arrest of one of its biggest stars has highlighted problems involving time and money that are forcing players to go abroad in the off-season.

titles: ECOWAS criticized over West African coups
descriptions: The Economic Community of West African States has reacted to putsches in the region with appeals, sanctions or troop deployments. But criticism of the bloc's inconsistent actions is growing.

titles: Can Indonesia and Germany build ties ahead of major summits?
descriptions: Indonesia has been invited by Germany to attend the G7 summit in June, raising hopes of more bilateral cooperation amid a thorny geopolitical landscape.

titles: EU threatens Vladimir Putin's Patriarch Kirill
descriptions: Patriarch Kirill of Moscow is an ally of Russian President Vladimir Putin and shares his anti-Western views. That's made him a target of European Union sanctions.

titles: Bank of England raises interest rates to 13-year-high
descriptions: It is the fourth month in a row the central bank's Monetary Policy Committee has voted for a rise. Policymakers are currently trying to stem inflation amid high energy prices sparked partly by Russia's war in Ukraine.

titles: Bitcoin boom spikes amid perceived risks
descriptions: Central African Republic and El Salvador have made Bitcoin legal tender and Panama has approved a bill to regulate crypto assets. Experts warn that nations that adopt crypto currencies risk instability.

titles: Documenta cancels talks amid antisemitism row
descriptions: The 2022 edition of the world-famous contemporary art show has suddenly axed discussions on the topic of artistic freedom, which had planned to address accusations of antisemitism.

titles: UK regional elections: Boris Johnson under scrutiny, historic vote in N. Ireland predicted
descriptions: The British prime minister has faced calls to step down after breaking COVID lockdown rules. In Northern Ireland, polls suggest the Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein could win the largest number of seats.

titles: New German open letter: 'Yes' to weapons for Ukraine
descriptions: Pianist Igor Levit, Nobel laureate Herta Müller and 55 other intellectuals have sent an appeal to Chancellor Olaf Scholz. They say Germany should supply heavy weapons to Ukraine.

titles: More than prayers: The faithful who aid Ukraine's front line
descriptions: In western Ukraine, a religious community led by Greek-Catholic monks is supporting the war effort by providing clothes and medical supplies for soldiers on the front line.

titles: China's COVID curbs rattle EU business confidence
descriptions: More European businesses in China are looking to shift their investments due to the country's strict coronavirus lockdowns, according to the European Chamber of Commerce.

titles: India: Policeman arrested for raping alleged child gang rape victim
descriptions: Police in India arrested an officer accused of raping a 13-year-old girl who had gone to the police station to file a gang-rape case.

titles: Germany plans documentation center on Nazi occupation in Europe
descriptions: Almost 80 years after the end of the Second World War, the German government has approved a concept for a documentation center in Berlin. Its focus: the effects of the Nazi era in Europe.

titles: What are millets and can they help create global food security?
descriptions: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has pushed food insecurity onto the table. Could an overlooked cereal help steady the situation and feed the global population in an era of climate crisis?

titles: Germany: Woman sentenced for poking holes in partner's condoms
descriptions: In what the judge described as a "historic" case, a woman has been found guilty of sexual assault after poking holes in her partner's condoms without his knowledge or consent.

titles: 'Navalny' documentary hits theaters in Germany
descriptions: Being an outspoken enemy of the Kremlin nearly cost Alexei Navalny his life. In this documentary that feels like a spy thriller, Putin's rival uncovers the facts about his poisoning.

titles: Germany's Scholz: 'Western Balkans belong in Europe'
descriptions: The leaders of Serbia and Kosovo met with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz in Berlin. Leaders voiced optimism at the prospect of both joining the European Union.

titles: Champions League: Jürgen Klopp's Liverpool to meet Real Madrid in 2018 re-run
descriptions: Real Madrid will meet Liverpool in the Champions League final following Madrid's late turnaround against Manchester City. It's a repeat of the 2018 final, with Jürgen Klopp determined not to let history repeat itself.

titles: Scholz stands firm on Ukraine visit amid criticism at home and abroad
descriptions: Chancellor Olaf Scholz addressed Ukraine's refusal to welcome President Frank-Walter Steinmeier again Wednesday, calling it "a problem for the German people." He said Kyiv needed to do its part to resolve the issue.

titles: Ukraine: How drones are changing the way of war
descriptions: The war in Ukraine shows that unmanned aerial vehicles are part of modern warfare. Drones have various tasks from aerial surveillance to missile defense.

titles: German Overshoot Day: 'We cannot continue like this'
descriptions: Germany has used more resources in the first third of 2022 than are sustainably available to it for an entire year. Here's what needs to change.

titles: North Korea cracks down on 'capitalist' pop culture
descriptions: Some North Koreans are defying strict fashion and style regulations to fight conformity. But their expressions of individualism could cost them their freedom.

titles: DW documentary 'Guardians of Truth' premieres in Berlin
descriptions: Turkish journalist Can Dündar and Mexican investigative journalist Anabel Hernandez both live in exile. They share their stories in a new documentary and at the Berlin premiere.

titles: COVID: Omicron variants are 'escaping previous immunity'
descriptions: You may be at risk of catching new COVID subvariants BA.4 or BA.5 even if you had the original omicron, as virologist Alex Sigal told DW's Science Unscripted.

titles: Germany warns prices may spike as Russia sanctions tighten
descriptions: Germany's Cabinet has wrapped two days and talks about the war in Ukraine and its impact on the German economy. The government warned that a planned EU oil embargo could cause supply problems and even higher inflation.

titles: Ukrainian troops get training in Germany
descriptions: Ukrainian soldiers are receiving weapons training on military bases in Germany. Legal advisers are discussing whether that makes Germany a party to war.

titles: Open letter about weapons deliveries to Ukraine draws criticism
descriptions: The publication of an open letter to German Chancellor Scholz signed by leading cultural figures has triggered a fierce debate about the planned delivery of heavy weapons to Ukraine — especially on social media.

titles: Can Algeria contribute to the EU's energy security?
descriptions: Timely decisions, long-term commitments and a broader vision could help the European Union increase ties with the Western Mediterranean. Algeria, with its large reserves, could enhance the bloc's energy security.

titles: DOK.fest Munich puts spotlight on Ukraine
descriptions: After a two-year break due to the pandemic, the documentary film festival is once again held in cinemas. A political thriller about Alexei Navalny opens the event.

titles: Will buying cars online really take off?
descriptions: Boosted by the popularity of electric automaker Tesla, more people than ever are buying vehicles online. UBS estimates the web will make up half of all car sales by 2030, but what will that mean for traditional dealers?

titles: Breed accounts for less than 10% of a dog's behavior
descriptions: If you're looking for a dog with a specific personality, its breed will tell you less than the environment in which it is raised, a new study suggests.

titles: To be fire and flame: German expressions with 'fire'
descriptions: May 4 marks International Firefighters' Day — a time to honor their work, while also learning some German expressions involving fire.

titles: Will an EU oil embargo put the lights out at Schwedt's refinery?
descriptions: As EU member states push for a Russian oil embargo, Germany's PCK Schwedt refinery is facing an uncertain future. It runs wholly on Russian imports, and many locals aren't so sure alternatives can be found in time.

titles: Carbon farming: Climate change solution or greenwashing?
descriptions: European agriculture produces millions of tons of CO2 every year. Could encouraging farmers to capture carbon on their land to sell credits to businesses help reduce emissions?

titles: 'Zombie TV': The disintegration of Russia's free press
descriptions: On World Press Freedom Day, a look at how Russia's media has evolved since the 1990s: 37 journalists have been murdered in Russia since Vladimir Putin took office in 2000.

titles: DW documentary series 'Guardians of Truth' looks at press freedom
descriptions: In this new DW documentary series, exiled Turkish journalist Can Dündar meets Mexican journalist Anabel Hernandez. Both have paid a high price for their fight for truth.

titles: Bundesliga: Leverkusen jubilant as top-four race tilts away from RB Leipzig
descriptions: Monday's doubleheader saw Leverkusen tighten their grip on a top four place in the Bundesliga. While Moussa Diaby and Patrik Schick shone for Leverkusen against Frankfurt, RB Leipzig crashed in Mönchengladbach.

titles: Germans split over heavy weapons deliveries to Ukraine
descriptions: The German public is divided on the issue of military support for Ukraine. Many fear the delivery of tanks and training of Ukrainian soldiers in Germany may drag the country into the war.

titles: Is India facing a post-pandemic employment crisis?
descriptions: India's job market is tightening, and skilled workers are finding it harder to enter the workforce. Government job drives and the informal economy have been unable to make up the difference.

titles: What are the COVID entry rules for travelers to European countries?
descriptions: Most European countries have lifted travel restrictions — despite ongoing high infection numbers. DW Travel has compiled this overview of EU rules.

titles: Record-breaking heat waves show we need to adapt to the climate crisis now
descriptions: India is just the latest country to face life-threatening temperatures before summer has even started. As extreme heat becomes more frequent around the world, how can affected areas adapt to remain livable?

titles: COVID travel restrictions: Germany
descriptions: Travel in Europe is subject to COVID-19 restrictions. The omicron variant has led to higher numbers of infections, which are often less severe. This is how Germany is responding to the current situation.

titles: The story of Germany's national anthem
descriptions: Created in the 19th century, the "Deutschlandlied" was sullied by the Nazis. Germany decided 70 years ago it would adopt only the third verse of the original song as its national anthem.

titles: Pride in defeat, growing support and hope for the future for Wolfsburg's women
descriptions: Wolfsburg lost on aggregate to Barcelona, but victory on the night and a clear philosophy off the field is earning them support — culminating in a record attendance on Saturday. The path forward for the club is clear.

titles: Europe cooperates on gas, as Russia turns off taps to Poland and Bulgaria
descriptions: Russia has halted gas exports to Poland and Bulgaria, ramping up the pressure on all EU states to find alternative suppliers. Some are working on cutting Russian gas altogether, others have plans to share with neighbors.

titles: Russia posts trained dolphins at Black Sea naval base, satellite images show
descriptions: Dolphin pens were moved to the Black Sea naval base around the time Russia invaded Ukraine, according to the US Naval Institute's analysis of satellite imagery.

titles: Europa League: RB Leipzig one step closer to a second final — but would a trophy bring acceptance?
descriptions: After victory over Rangers, RB Leipzig are one step closer to reaching their first-ever European final. The club hope a trophy might legitimize their place in German football, but are there some things money can't buy?

titles: Origin of hepatitis outbreak in kids is still unknown
descriptions: Doctors are puzzled by an unknown strain of hepatitis presenting in children, which has in some cases caused liver failure. But they are learning more. Symptoms are like jaundice.

titles: Elvira Nabiullina: The central banker Vladimir Putin is relying on to clean up Russia's economic mess
descriptions: Elvira Nabiullina has charmed many in the West with her policymaking — and clothing choices. Analysts say she has blemished her reputation by remaining at the helm to help sustain Putin's war machine in Ukraine.

titles: About a million people live near dangerous dams in Brazil
descriptions: Data analysis by DW reveals many Brazilians live near dams that, without proper maintenance and governmental oversight, could be deadly in the case of failure.

titles: Eintracht Frankfurt show 'Europa League face' against West Ham in London
descriptions: Frankfurt lead their Europa League semifinal following an absorbing first leg in London. The German club continue to show their best form in Europe as they beat West Ham to hold the advantage ahead of the return leg.

titles: Cashing in: No payment problems for Russian tourists in Turkey
descriptions: Turkey is trying to attract more Russian tourists by expanding the usage of the Russian Mir payment system in the country, as it seeks to bypass payment bottleneck created by Western sanctions.

titles: Putin and Parkinson's: What experts say about his health
descriptions: A video released by the Kremlin last weekend shows Putin in seemingly bad health. Some commentators and tabloids claim he has Parkinson's. What do doctors think?

titles: Swiping right on climate love: Dating apps and environmental advocacy
descriptions: Dating platforms have noticed their users are hot for climate issues and are incorporating features to help them connect with each other. But how useful are additions like OkCupid's climate advocate badge?

titles: Germany top buyer of Russian energy since Ukraine invasion began: report
descriptions: Russian fossil fuel exports are undermining sanctions imposed on the Kremlin over its invasion of Ukraine, a study says. Germany and the EU remain the biggest buyers of Russian energy.

titles: Mars probe discovers 'shocking' new aurora
descriptions: The Emirates Mars Mission says it's a first: They have spotted a worm-like aurora that stretches halfway round Mars. It looks like our northern lights.

titles: Europe's 'middle class' clubs battle to save Champions League
descriptions: UEFA are proposing to increase the number of games in the Champions League and offer a safety net to its richest clubs. The plans have been derided as a Super League by the back door and some clubs are fighting back.

titles: Turning the tide on land degradation
descriptions: Human activity has led to widespread land degradation and put our very survival as a species at risk. But by reversing course, we can tackle climate change and biodiversity loss — and make a better life for billions.

titles: Warsaw and Budapest split over Russian energy ties
descriptions: Poland and Hungary have shared a tilt towards the nationalist right, bound also by a mutual distrust of the EU. But their relations with Russia are anything but alike. DW explores the energy ties that bind — and don't.

titles: Elon Musk buys Twitter: What it means for the platform
descriptions: Musk's vision of creating a bastion of free speech with less moderation and a higher bar for removing offending tweets could also lead to more abusive content, disinformation and hate speech, critics fear.

titles: Endometriosis: The long wait for a diagnosis
descriptions: Sabrina Lobing waited more than a decade for a diagnosis that explained her symptoms. Now she knows she has endometriosis — a disease that little is known about and yet is very common.

titles: How Filip Kostic became the modern Bundesliga wingback
descriptions: Eintracht Frankfurt are in the final four of the Europa League, and they couldn't have done it without Kostic. It's not always been easy, but Jasmine Baba explains how the club got the best out of their Serbian winger.

titles: Scientists sound alarm bells on noise pollution
descriptions: The rumble of road traffic and trains, the bustle of the bar downstairs or the roar of a plane taking off - noise is a problem that is increasingly hurting health and disrupting ecosystems.

titles: Afghan women athletes: prisoners in their own homes
descriptions: It's eight months since the Taliban took control of Afghanistan and the country has slipped down the news agenda. 'The world forgets about us,' says Friba Rezayee, the first Afghan woman to compete at the Olympics.

titles: RECOMMENDED — What does a US cryptocurrency firm want from a lower-tier UK football club?
descriptions: Crawley Town have become the first professional football club to be bought by a cryptocurrency firm. The new owners promise to "shake up the status quo" and recruit global fans with NFTs. Is this new dawn what it seems?

titles: Beyond ecology: The trees at the heart of our culture
descriptions: From Ireland to the Amazon to Kenya, trees can hold traditional or even sacred value. DW takes a look at trees and forests of cultural importance to communities around the world. Some are under threat.

titles: Opinion: Bayern Munich's 10th title - joy or relief?
descriptions: Bayern Munich have won their 10th straight Bundesliga title, sparking renewed conversation about the competitive issues at the top of German football. Perhaps the biggest concern though, is the question of fun.

titles: Bundesliga: Bayern Munich's 10th title prompts celebration — but also concern
descriptions: Ten league titles in a row should be cause for celebration, one might think. But Bayern Munich's latest triumph is accompanied by acute concern, both in Munich and further afield.

titles: EU reaches deal on major law aiming to regulate tech giants
descriptions: As per the Digital Services Act (DSA), tech giants such as Facebook and Google will be expected to moderate illegal content on their platforms. It's the second part of the bloc's project seeking to rein in tech giants.

titles: Shanghai COVID lockdown threatens new export delays
descriptions: Nearly a third of goods leaving the Port of Shanghai are held up due to a strict COVID lockdown. The delays are set to exacerbate a supply chain crisis that has caused shortages and price rises across the world.

titles: Let's talk about salt — how unhealthy is it really?
descriptions: Most people consume too much salt — with potentially massive effects for their health. But it's possible to find a healthy balance.

titles: So you want to live forever?
descriptions: Spoiler: You probably won't be able to live forever, even if you want to. How about settling for a life free from age-related ailments like Alzheimer's or arthritis instead?

titles: COVID: In a crowd of unmasked people, can a mask still protect you?
descriptions: Many countries around the world are easing mask mandates. If no one else is masking up, should you?

titles: From Mumbai to Paris, the cities investing in the planet
descriptions: This Earth Day, we show how city councils and mayors have stepped up to boldly decarbonize in the face of national government inaction.

titles: Energy crisis: What role can Germany's oil and gas sector play?
descriptions: As Germany looks to ditch Russian oil and gas for good, its domestic energy industry is a key side actor — but can it step up to the plate? We search for clues in the village where Germany's oil sector was born.

titles: Climate crisis: How to cope with eco-anxiety
descriptions: Does worrying about climate change keep you up at night? Growing numbers of people are struggling with eco-anxiety, or distress about the state of the planet. If you're one of them, these expert tips might help.

titles: Glass windows kill billions of birds a year. Scientists are working to change that
descriptions: Conservationists are trying to convince governments and building owners around the world to introduce changes to stop birds from flying into reflective glass. Experts say the solutions are surprisingly simple.

titles: The thriving gardens at the heart of Rio de Janeiro's favelas
descriptions: In one of the most dangerous and deprived neighborhoods in the Brazilian city, residents are now finding hope and employment by growing fruit and vegetables.

titles: European Space Agency halts cooperation with Russia on moon missions
descriptions: The European Space Agency's move marks the latest in the deterioration of space-based relations with Russia.

titles: New omicron variants: What we know so far
descriptions: A new omicron subvariant, BA.2.12.1, is spreading in the US and India. German Health Minister Lauterbach has expressed concern about the highly contagious coronavirus variant. Here's what we know so far.

titles: China turns cities into sponges to stop flooding
descriptions: In the coming decade, China is expanding its plans for sponge cities. They can help prevent flooding, promote biodiversity and cut emissions. But what exactly are these cities and how do they work?

titles: Germany: Over 1 in 4 people have 'migrant background'
descriptions: The number of people with "migrant background" — foreigners and people with foreign roots — keeps rising in Germany, with Turkey, Poland and Russia the top three countries of familial origin.

titles: Cities are major polluters: Can we make them climate neutral?
descriptions: Spewing most of the world's heat-trapping gases, fast-growing cities need to be transformed into clean, low emissions ecosystems in the struggle against climate breakdown.

titles: Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti: ISS is a 'beacon of hope'
descriptions: Ahead of the launch of her Minerva mission to the International Space Station, Cristoforetti talked about the cooperation among European, US and Russian crew members in light of the ongoing Russian invasion of Ukraine.
